row.AboutMe:
Hi, I'm not really a person.

I'm a background process that helps keep this site clean!

I do things like

  • Randomly poke old unanswered questions every hour so they get some attention
  • Own community questions and answers so nobody gets unnecessary reputation from them
  • Own downvotes on spam/evil posts that get permanently deleted
  • Own suggested edits from anonymous users

Stack Overflow Valued Associate

Twitter: @Nick_Craver
Public CV: On StackOverflow Careers
Flickr: Photos on new house progress, where I work, etc.

I mostly live in the C#/Linq2SQL/Raw SQL world, but at night I secretly masquerade as someone who pretends to know JavaScript & jQuery.
Disclaimer: I have no idea what I'm talking about, all my answers are guesses!

Developer on the StackOverflow team. Find me on

Twitter

Stack Overflow Valued Associate #00003

Stack Overflow Valued Associate, Community Manager and Technical Evangelist for Stack Overflow and the Stack Exchange network.

I've written (with help), several userscripts for SE sites and chats. They add additional features and keyboard shortcuts to SE sites and SE chats. Userscripts aren't just for Firefox. Chrome, Opera, Safari, and even Internet Explorer support them also.

I also wrote StackFlair (StackApps link), a single combined flair image for the SE network. Show off your flair in user profiles, forum signatures, etc!

Feature requests and contributions to both projects are welcome on Github, get forking! (:

I am a moderator on WebApps.SE, a StackExchange site for end-users of web applications.

I use Six to Eight, an iOS app for the SE network of sites.

I'm @rchern on Twitter.

I started the Security proposal in Area-51, you should follow it!!!

My passion is in.... well, it changes about every 4 months, but it always involves programming. (Right now it's encryption).

I usually learn by picking up a book, reading it cover to cover, and then buying another book on the same subject which I never end up reading.

I own my own Dev-Server, Developed and published several websites including my most recent, masadatactical.com, and worked on several, one of which, was MTH Trains.

I have published 2 apps to the android market, which can be found here.

In general, I'm a pretty awesome person (not Chuck Norris awesome, but sometimes I come pretty close)

I am a project manager for a Pacific Northwest software as a service provider. I believe in using the latest, cutting edge technologies to get the job done.

I am currently working on helping sales teams increase their chances of making a sale on their leads using Live Chat Software. Each lead has a specific cost that is only mitigated by making a sale. Check out our website to see How It Works.

Andrew Kozak (@andrewkozak) was born and raised at the Jersey Shore although his fair skin wouldn't give that away.  He is conversant in most modern technologies, has been programming since the third grade, remembers life before HTML had a version number, and prefers the hose for chasing kids off his lawn.  He enjoys writing and is an outspoken advocate of English spacing, Oxford commas, and Roman quotes.  Andrew also enjoys traveling, training, and studying a variety of subjects.  When not in front of a screen or under a bar, he practices calligraphy, occasionally judges costuming competitions, and continues to work on speaking as many languages as he feels he should.

My company is hiring database people! Message me on LinkedIn if you're interested.

Notable posts:

  • Debunking a persistent SQL Server myth about TRUNCATE.
  • Debunking another SQL Server myth about variable declarations causing proc recompiles.
  • Understanding how certain SQL Server functions dynamically cast their output.
  • Using a recursive CTE to find the first ancestor in a hierarchy to satisfy certain conditions.

I am a Database Developer and Administrator. My specialty is database design and development (mostly on SQL Server) and my technical hobby is to develop impactful, highly specialized visualizations (generally using Processing).

I also have a couple of years of experience with the following:

  • SQL Server Integration Services (SSIS) Development
  • SQL Server 2005 and 2008 Administration

  • Oracle 9i administration

    The Oracle instance I manage is clustered on Windows 2003 using Oracle Fail Safe. I swear I must be one of 3 people in the world alive with this kind of experience.
